content.description:
Aeneas envisions Helen’s future.

1 “Scilicetscilicet: no doubt, probably haec Spartam incolumisincolumis, -is: unharmed patriasque Mycenas

aspiciet, partoquepario, parere, peperi, partus: produce ibit regina triumpho?

Coniugiumque domumque patres natosque videbit

IliadumIlias, Iliadis, f.: a Trojan woman turba et PhrygiisPhrygius, -a, -um: Phrygian, Trojan comitata ministris?

5 Occiderit ferro Priamus? Troia arserit igni?

Dardanium totiens sudarit sanguine litus?

Non ita. Namque etsi nullum memorabile nomen

feminea in poena est, habet haec victoria laudem;

exstinxisse nefas tamen et sumpsisse merentes

10 laudabor poenas, animumque explesse iuvabit

ultricisultrix, -cis: avenging flammae et cinerescinis, -eris, m.: ash satiasse meorum.”
content.question: Line 2 (aspiciet . . . triumpho) alludes to which Roman practice?

choices.label: A celebration of a military victory

content.answer: A celebration of a military victory

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 2.B: Describe historical and cultural contexts of Latin texts.
